text: in the UK were eating more rice than
ever in fact we now eat at least four
times more rice and rice products than

because of their healthy reputation but
at the same time I've also noticed lots

rice has quite high levels of arsenic in

is well known as a poison but most of us

into food levels tend to be higher in
rice because it's grown under flooded
conditions last year the EU brought in

rice products i'm meeting professor and

who's been researching the subject for
nearly 20 years
I must admit and it had never ever
occurred to me that there was arsenic in

doses you find it in does it really
affect your health totally we know that
low levels chronic exposure to arsenic
causes a wide range of disease and over

risks of cancer we know that if you have

it causes a range of other developmental

gross weights development its IQ
development are all linked to arsenic
exposure Andy has tested levels of
arsenic in different types of rice and
compared them with other cereal crops he
found that white basmati rice has five
times as much arsenic as wheat or barley
mother white rice typically has 10 times
the amount and brown rice 20 times these
levels are all below the new legal limit
set in Europe Andy is still concerned
all they've done is set them at levels
which are typically find in rice so
they've done nothing does she make rice
growers or rice food manufacturers do
anything about it and I would argue very
strongly that they're not fine to have
those levels the UN Food and Agriculture
Organization who advise on acceptable
limits said levels need to be low enough
to protect public health but still allow
sufficient cravin availability of rice
in the developing world
another concern Andy has is with rice

giving young children because it's

because of the arsenic content the legal
limits for arsenic in children's rice
products like baby rice are set at half
the adult amantha but puffed rice
cereals don't have to meet the child
requirements because they are deemed as
not being directly marketed at children
the Food Standards Agency also advises
that children under four and a half
should not be given rice drinks as these
